title: Is streaming the best way to discover new music? What are some alternatives? - Quora

response.answer_text: Short answer: no. Find an experimental radio station like Where the Music Matters Long answer: I don’t think that streaming is the best alternative because, from everything I’ve seen, streaming recommends things based upon what you’re already listening to, IE, more of the same. Meaning, it’s probably going to ‘curate’ something based upon the decade, genre (new wave, metal, etc), and ‘related’ acts from those two criteria. Likelihood is, you’ll already be familiar with those ‘associated’ acts. I call this the Pandora principle. I’m an 80’s kid. Let’s say I want to listen to some post-punk like PiL. OK, great. I put in ‘PiL Radio’ and I hear some PiL. Maybe then I hear some Gang of Four. So far, so good, right? Sure. But then, BOOM! Tears for Fears. What the actual heck? TFF is from the 80’s, and could loosely be lumped into the same ‘category’ as PiL and Gang of Four (meaning, non-mainstream music of the 80’s). Although TFF had lots of radio play, the fact remains, they’re considered more an ‘alternative’ act than a ‘pop’ act. And to Pandora, that’s all that matters. (BTW, TFF is not post-punk and doesn’t belong on a playlist with PiL). This also seems to be the case where Spotify is concerned - more of what they see you currently ‘like’ at the moment. This forces people into musical bubbles - you can like Metallica, but you’ll never see Johnny Cash pop up in a ‘recommended based upon’. And from a computer’s viewpoint, that makes perfect sense. Old country music vs. metal. Does not compute. However, it’s perfectly reasonable for you to like both artists. But that doesn’t mean you’ll get the opportunity to discover that based on a streaming algorithm.

As an artist I guess I would be crazy to ignore streaming but I personally use Google and YouTube as my discovery sources. Google will give you genre based stations magazines and blogs, youtube with give you the music and a way to contact the artist. hope this helps :) Peter
